author: radarbot
body:
Why did you buy CRWD if you don't know the difference between them and ZS, FTNT, PANW, NET, etc?

I'm not trying to shame, but I would do more research on understanding why you're owning a stock. It seems you were just riding momentum.

I own CRWD, and I still believe in it. Right now, it has a polarizing view. The stock tanked because JP lowered the PT to $250 and marked it as underperform. But similarly, Mizuho has a PT of $360 with a buy rating.

CRWD won't release Q3 numbers until December 1. Their last 10Q was on September 1: https://ir.crowdstrike.com/node/9601/html

Their revenue is up 70% from the same quarter a year ago comparing 2021 and 2020. They're on target for 1.1Bn in revenue for 2021 with a P/S of 50. They have margins of 70%. Compare that to NET which has revenue targets for 2021 of $660M with margins of 79% with a P/S of 100.

Both are highly valued, but if you believe that security is a secular tailwind and CRWD's cloud security offering is competitive you should stick with it.

Here is CRWD's investor presentation: https://ir.crowdstrike.com/static-files/547e5c92-3594-4eef-9dfc-9eca37b635f4

Here is ZS: https://ir.zscaler.com/static-files/9ced1dd4-29b7-4892-80e1-bcb2fe0169da

Here is PANW: https://s22.q4cdn.com/606234439/files/doc_financials/2021/q4/Q4'21-Earnings-Presentation-vF-(1).pdf

Again, not to be a jerk, but if you read those presentations and you can't tell the difference in the offerings between those companies I would consider getting out of the space. Only invest in industries you understand, so you can pivot and adapt appropriately.

author: The_user_of
body:
I sold all of my PTON puts that I got this morning for 64% profit this afternoon.

Felt good.  Then saw AH.  Don't know why I paperhanded it, I had planned on holding through earnings.

Same with FTNT, but only sold half my calls to lock in the gains.  AH pop.

author: MaintenanceCall
body:
Cyber is an enormous sector. Lots of room, but there are tons of companies. Okta, DocuSign, BlackBerry now, Fortinet, CrowdStrike, Zscaler, Mimecast, Arqit, Palo Alto, Rapid7, Cisco, . . . The list is long. And then the are all the private ones, too. 
  
ETFs like HACK is probably a better way to go.

author: slow_down_kid
body: Honest question: what the fuck does Fortinet even do anymore? I used their multi-line phone system with auto attendants for a hotel I ran and honestly there are so many better options. That, plus their support fucking sucked and they stopped supporting the product I bought maybe a year after I purchased it. I vaguely remember them moving toward different industry but I couldn’t tell you what.

author: badpauly
body:
This is a list of the top 20 companies that experienced the largest change in insider shares in the last seven (7) days.
The SEC defines an insider as any officer, director or 10% shareholder. It is not illegal for these people to buy or sell their own shares.
In fact, since most of them get paid in stock options, it is expected. However, it is illegal for them to trade on inside information
that has not been made public. So for example if there are drug trial results that are bad and not public,
insiders cannot dump shares. That said, many people have observed that insiders - in general - seem to have a good
track record at timing their purchases.  All trades that are marked as part of a 10b5 plan are excluded from this report.

author: Deeperfuckinvalue
body:
I am officially down 35k with my life savings and currently decided to live in my car :) i started with scalping , had some success but couldnt see it doing long term. Switched to spreads and thought of doing PUt credit spreads and iron condors. Took positions in GPN, CAR thinking they were the safest play ( what could go wrong with AVIS). Oh well ran up 300% the day after earnings. Last week took apple bear credit spread and guess what , ALL TIME HIGH :) so not sure if anything wrong with my trading or just bad luck ! 

Are you still doing spreads ?

author: More_Surround
body: I sold PayPal, Global Payments and Visa two weeks ago. I couldn’t continue the losses and figured I could make money elsewhere.

author: half-spin
body:
There is already the original metaverse, called second life. I was blown away that Zuck did not even once mention it. they are basically making a more modern version of this, and they are going to try to shove their oculus to everyone's face. 

The value proposition is valid, it is that 3d gaming is the future of social chatter. 

The VR push  however is going  to be a major flop. No amount of high tech is going to change the fact that a blindfold is not something you want to wear for long. Also, Facebook sells attention, and AR is the opposite of attention, it's distraction. 

Unity will benefit enormously from this,  but mobile gaming will lose a lot of momentum for a long time. 

Here is what people buy in second life: Avatars, avatar skins, avatar clothes, penises, vaginas, sexy clothes, even more sexy clothes. Basically take the most superficial and vain doll-dressing app and pump it up by 10 times or so, that's the future. No, it won't be the hub for tech and work and education and research, it will be as vapid and vain as facebook and instagram are now. 

Facebook will probably push its own, controlled and censored "crypto" to people. This will be their most controversial move,  but maybe their lobbyists are already in agreement with US govt. This is about ensuring that the next global payments system is controlled by the US govt.

author: LegitimateShameHands
body: Gus Richard upgraded AMD on October 27th and downgraded them today while upgrading INTC. How can you change your mind and upgrade and again downgrade within 4 days wtf

author: mrlumpus98
body: My intel $47.50c for 11/5 might actually print

author: mrkaluzny
body: Don’t sell AAPL. I think they’re going to 200 in 22 (depends on chips shortage) new MacBooks are flying off the shelves AAPL is supply bound but the margin on their own devices is higher then Intel-based ones. And this is not priced in IMO.

author: Wazoo_destroyer
body:
1. Intel has been heavily supporting their share price, where would it be without them? Sub $40?
2. Their p/e ratio reflects their market saturation, who are they going to steal market share from? They are the incumbent.
3. And they will need every cent to build new fabs.
4. Never say never, Intel is going to have to take on massive debt, in addition to the 30B they carry at present, to fund IDM2.0. If the CFO is looking for cash the dividend is easy pickings.

Their new weird CEO has stated intc is aiming for leadership in 2025, 3-4 years away. One thing to remember is this super cycle aside, the semiconductor biz is cyclical, boom and bust. In 3 or 4 years when demand drops off and both TSMC and INTC have built massive chip foundry capacity, where will the customers go? To the foundry with the best process. Whoever has overbuilt will suffer.

author: Wazoo_destroyer
body:
> The nm stuff isn't really accurate for any of them anymore so not worried about a rebrand.

Gate leakage and ultimately performance per watt is the real measure of a process. If one compares Tsmc and Intel fabbed processors on what both call 7nm, the tsmc silicon is easily better.
